review: I'm a sucker for specs, so even though I got my Fire Stick free with my Sling subscription, I probably would have picked this one over Roku or Chromecast anyway. After two months of daily use, I have run into few problems: the stick was easy to connect to my wifi, and it's only lost the connection twice (on the same day, so the problem was probably with my internet). The remote takes a bit of getting used to...the command to exit out of a show without exiting the app should be more intuitive.My big complaint is that there is no available browser, so my use of the Fire stick is limited to videos that have apps on amazon. The yoga website I subscribe to, for example, doesn't have an app on amazon, and they don't put their subscriber vids on youtube, so I still have to plug in my computer to do yoga videos on TV. That just seems silly: there's even a dedicated browser for Kindle Fire, so why isn't it on Fire Stick? Better yet, why aren't Google apps (Chrome, Calendar, etc) available for Amazon devices?  I expect that Amazon wants to coerce customers to stick with Amazon services (shocker!!), but I don't like buying devices that limit the choices of the consumer in order to promote proprietary services (Hi Apple! :D). My annoyance with this limitation will probably make me replace this Fire Stick eventually with a device that has a web browser.  Incidentally, because of this I've also decided to get a Android tablet instead of a Kindle Fire.
author: Elaine
